--- title: "Document Formats" subtitle: "Session 1: Getting to know Quarto" author: "Cynthia Huang" date: 2023-07-19 format: revealjs metadata-files: - ../_slides.yml --- # Anatomy of a Quarto Document ## Basic Components {.smaller} ::: {layout-ncol="2"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ```` --- title: "Anatomy of a Quarto Document" --- ## R ```{r} head(mtcars) ``` ## STATA ```stata version 13 use censas tabulate region summarize marriage_rate divorce_rate median_age if state!="Nevada" ``` The script above is from the [Section 16.1](https://www.stata.com/manuals13/u16.pdf) of the *Stata 13 Manual* ```` ::: ::: - **Metadata:** an (optional) YAML header - **Content:** markdown syntax - **Code:** executed by `knitr` (R) or `jupyter` (python) ::: ## YAML Metadata - "Yet Another Markup Language" or "YAML Ain't Markup Language" ``` yaml key: value ``` ::: incremental - Control whole document or project options and metadata - If **YAML header** is missing, Quarto defaults apply. - Available options differ by format: HTML, PDF, Websites ::: ## Markdown Content ::: notes not covered in detail, but we will briefly look at some features ::: - Simple text formatting: - `# Heading` - `_italics_`, `**bold**`, `` `code` `` - `[linked phrase](http://example.com)` - Content features: - Figures - Tables - References ## Code Blocks ::: notes not covered beyond displaying code ::: - Chunks of code between ```` ``` ````s. - Syntax highlighting for [\~140 Languages](https://github.com/jgm/skylighting/tree/master/skylighting-core/xml): ```` ```stata ```` - Executable R/python/Julia code starts with: ```` ```{r} ```` # Quarto Formats ::: notes One important thing that YAML metadata controls are format options. YAML will also be important for websites ::: ## Many Quarto formats & features {.smaller} :::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} where to, whole doc features - render options (YAML) - html then pdf - YAML features - title - keep tex - render HTML again -- show multi-format ::: ::: follow - Open `my_first_doc.qmd` again in RStudio. - What is the default rendering format? - Add PDF format options and keep the intermediate `.tex` file: ``` yaml --- format: pdf: keep-tex: true html: default --- ``` - Render the document as a PDF. - **Extension**: Can you preview the HTML again? _[HINT: Use `quarto preview` in the Terminal]_ ::: # YAML ## YAML options Indentation matters! ``` yaml --- format: html: toc: true code-fold: true --- ``` . . . A sneak preview of YAML for websites: ```{.yaml filename="_quarto.yml"} --- project: type: website output-dir: _site --- ``` ## Why YAML? To avoid manually typing out all the options, every time when rendering via the CLI: . . . ``` bash quarto render document.qmd --to html ```
. . . ``` bash quarto render document.qmd --to html -M code-fold:true ```
. . . ``` bash quarto render document.qmd --to html -M code-fold:true -P alpha:0.2 -P ratio:0.3 ``` ## YAML validation {.smaller} - Invalid: No space after `:` ``` yaml --- format:html --- ``` - Invalid: Read as missing ``` yaml --- format: html --- ``` - Valid, but needs next object ``` yaml --- format: html: --- ``` ## YAML validation {.smaller} There are multiple ways of formatting valid YAML: - Valid: There's a space after `:` ``` yaml format: html ``` - Valid: There are 2 spaces a new line and no trailing `:` ``` yaml format: html ``` - Valid: `format: html` with selections made with proper indentation ``` yaml format: html: toc: true ``` ## Quarto linting ::: notes how to validate all these options? ::: Lint, or a linter, is a static code analysis tool used to flag programming errors, bugs, stylistic errors and suspicious constructs.
![](images/lint-rstudio.png){fig-alt="Linter showing message for badly formatted YAML."} ::: aside Source: ::: ## Quarto YAML Intelligence RStudio + VSCode provide rich tab-completion - start a word and tab to complete, or `Ctrl + space` to see all available options.
